oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Printed advertisement for "Proposals for Iron Head Blocks" from the Quartermaster General's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; National cemeteries; Graves; Gravestones; Advertisements
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement dealing with iron head blocks for graves of soldiers buried in national cemeteries. Advertisement includes number of head blocks requested by location (8-12,000 for Memphis and 15-20,000 for Nashville), as well as the dimensions and information required for each block. Each is to be 9x10x12 inches, made of hollow cast iron and include the name, rank, regiment, arm, company, corps, and date of death.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Quartermaster's Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: William Alonzo Wainwright, United States Assistant Quartermaster Records, 1861-1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1862, the Quartermaster's Department assumed responsibility for burial of war dead and care of national cemeteries.
